0.title: A new Rankin dinghy
0.content: by Owen Oâ€™Connell . In early February, 2021, Dave Oâ€™Keeffe and Owen Oâ€™Connell set out to build a new Rankin, the first in 24 years, and only the second (Dave built himself a Rankin in 1997) since the close of the Rankin workshop in the late 1980s. This was made possible because Dave had purchased the Rankin boat mould when the workshop closed, and of course, he had the skills needed for building a boat. In this blog post, significant milestones along the way are highlighted. February 9, 2021 . Transom knee made up using a template on our new router table. February 11, 2021 . Transom and Transom Stiffner made up using a 9mm plywood template . February 15, 2021 . Transom glued up and rough shaped . February 16, 2021 . Fore foot cut from 1 7/8 inch thick Iroko using original Rankin template. February 16, 2021 . We screwed and glued all the centreline timbers (transom, transom knee, hog, fore foot and apron) over the Rankin mould / jig. The mould is the original mould that was built by Eric Rankin and used by himself and his brother David from the early 1960â€™s to the late 1980â€™s. Dave Oâ€™Keeffe purchased the mould when the contents of the Rankin workshop at Lynchâ€™s Quay were sold off and has had it in safe keeping every since. February 17, 2021 . Fairing the apron to the mould and to accept the future planking. February 18, 2021 . Today we made up a template to match the sheer line of the mould, this will then be matched against an existing Rankin dinghy and then used to cut the curve for a new â€œdinosaurâ€! . February 19, 2021 . Having faired the template to match the inside curve of the gunwale, we laid it out on a large slab of pitch pine 11â€™ long x 14â€ wide x 4 1/2â€ thick and started to cut. February 20, 2021 . The â€œDinosaurâ€ being glued and clamped and fixed with coach bolts and 150mm long screws, meanwhile Dave started fairing the hog and transom to recieve the garboard planks. February 22, 2021 . The â€œDinosaurâ€ now cleaned down and in its upright position with floor brackets fitted, the angle blocks still need to be secured. The curved face has been faired with electric plane, then block plane and finished off with the sander. February 24, 2021 . Drawing down the 1st of 6 sheets of 6mm ply (Robins Super Elite Plus) for cutting using the garboard template. Then scarfing the fore and aft sections of the plank together. The plastic is used to resist the glue and keep the timber clean. February 24, 2021 . Final fairing on the Hog ,Forefoot and Apron with a dry run on the bendy bit of the Garboard, to check the lands. February 25, 2021 . More clamps arrived today, meanwhile we dry fitted the starboard garboard, scarfed and glued the port garboard and cut out the next set of planks . February 26, 2021 . Drilling a 30mm dia hole in in each of the 44 number 400 x 60 x 25 mm thick pieces of plywood, which will form the spikes on the back of the Dinosaur. The newly arrived Epoxy delivery ready for glueing up the planking. February 28, 2021 . Finally we got the 1st garboard plank glued up and clamped on the mould yesterday; clamps and tape removed today. Only 13 more to go!! . March 1, 2021 . Dry run using ratchet straps to hold down the 2nd Garboard, screws and blocks did not prove man enough at the turn of the Garboard around the Forefoot. Time was also spent setting up the spikes on theâ€Dinosaurâ€. March 4, 2021 . 60 years on and some things never change. March 4, 2021 . The 3rd plank glued and clamped today, using U shaped rebar and wooden wedges. The â€œDinosaurâ€ nearing completion, this will be used to bend the gunnels when the time comes. March 5, 2021 . 4th plank on, glued and clamped. Dave applying glue to the land of the 5th plank, the yellow tape on the reverse of the plank is to protect against glue squeeze out. March 10, 2021 . Checking the fairing on the bottom of the 5th plank by setting up stations at every 100mm on the 4th plank of the existing Rankin and recording the visible width. Then transfering that information on to the new 4th plank and marking the bottom edge of the rough cut 5th plank. Dave then fairs to this line. Planks 8 and 9 were fitted today. March 11, 2021 . Today was cutting out planks 13 & 14; yes the last ones (also known as the â€œWhiskeyâ€ plank) The planks are cut using the templates we previously made. They are cut 6mm over size to allow for any change in the lay of the plank as it is bent on the mould. Plank 10 was fixed today as well as gluing up the scarfs on planks 11 & 12. March 14, 2021 . Each plank in made from near enough a sheet and a half length of ply, a scarf (scarph) joint is made to connect the two pieces, the plywood being 6 mm thick means the scarf is 54mm wide ( a 1 in 9 slope). The joint is glued and clamped. The finished product shows the â€œSâ€ shape of the top 2 sets of planks on the Rankin - thereâ€™s more to planks than meets the eye. March 15, 2021 . Working on the 11th plank, following the final dry fit, a datum line is drawn the length of the plank. The width of the plank is measured either side of this datum every 100mm along the length of the plank. This information will be used to produce CNC planks in the future (the tape is to record the values while keeping the plank clean) The plank is then glued and clamped, lots of clamps were used in fixing this plank so not enough clamps to do plank 12 today. March 22, 2021 . Plank 14 (the Whiskey plank) fitted this morning. No time to celebrate ğŸº as we are moving on to fit the keel this afternoon. March 23, 2021 . Dave fitted the deadwood which was scribed to the shape of the hull and glued on above the keel and below the future apron. Meanwhile I opened out the slot for the daggerboard and made up the running boards out of 27 x 17mm strips of Iroko. March 23, 2021 . The Keel was shaped, fitted, glued and braced from the ceiling. It was made from a piece of 10ft long, 120mm x 40mm Iroko. The gap in the middle is for the dagger board slot. Cheek pieces will be added after the slot is cut to final dimensions. March 24, 2021 . Several workfaces today. | The apron was rough shaped, glued and braced in place. | The front end of the keel and the deadwood started to be shaped. | The cheeks of the daggerboard box were shaped, glued and clamped in place. | The first of the running boards was glued and braced in place ( this proved problematic so a jig was made up to hold them in place for when we glue them tomorrow). | Completed trimming and fairing the planks at the transom. | . March 25, 2021 . A forest of braces holding down the running boards while 2 sets of jigs hold then in place.The signature Rankin shape of the stem can be seen as Dave continued to shape the apron. March 26, 2021 . Turned the right way up today. R to L: mould, new shell, finished product. March 28, 2021 . 61 years after the 1st Rankin came off this very same mould a new Rankin is born. Many thanks to Bud for providing the workshop space to carry out this very special project. March 30, 2021 . After the excitement of turning the boat the boring task of cleaning the glue lines progresses. April 2, 2021 . Glue lines and glue stains cleaned off the shell, next stage is to make the templates and jig for the install of the twarths and stern seat assembly as advised by Mike O Sullivan (who spent his misspent youth in the Rankin Workshop). April 6, 2021 . New block plane and spokeshave eased the work involved in making the templates for the aft seat assembly. April 14, 2021 . Templates and jigs, the new seat assembly jig completed and on the wall with the rest of the Rankin templates. April 15, 2021 . Making templates for the bottom (floor)boards, used heavy guage paper fixed over the boards of the existing Rankin using Prit Stick and then cut around the boards with a scissors to make the templates. The templates were then peeled off and laid on a sheet of ply, marked and cut out with a jigsaw. Final fairing done with a block plane. â€¦ continued in part 2 ğŸ”— .

2.title: The Rankin Revival
2.content: by Maurice Kidney . Beginnings . The Rankin Revival as it came to be called was started in 2014 when Conor English and Maurice Kidney got together and put together a database of Rankin boats and their owners. Much of the boat information came from a meeting of boat owners that was held 4 years previously in Peg Twomeyâ€™s bar in 2010. Its aim was to revive interest in what was a well-loved local boat. This meeting was unsuccessful, and another meeting was organised in Jan 2015 in the Donkey Bar. The objectives of the meeting were - . | Expand boat register | Provide help to boat owners by shared knowledge | Direct unused boats to new owners | Set up a structure to save/repair damaged boats | Build up the historical profile of the class And most importantly - . | Arrange fun events on the water to encourage use of boats | . The meeting, being well attended by boat owners and the objectives being well received, the Rankin Group/Class as we know it today was formed. Finding and repairing Rankins . The first success in the search for missing Rankins came when the Helga ğŸ”— â€“ Eric Rankinâ€™s own boat was located and bought from Mick Brennan in Kinsale in 2016. Owen O Connell and Eithne Twomey became the new owners. Fig.1 - Helga, 2016; Photo: Mary Kidney A big regret looking back is turning down the â€˜Flower Potâ€™. This was a Rankin in Guileen, in East Cork. She was in bad condition and deemed too far gone to restore. When we had a change of heart and went back to get her she had been turned into a Garden feature and planted up accordingly. Lesson learned. Fig.2 - The flower pot, 1916. The next Rankin acquired by the group in 2016 was Damien Ahernâ€™s R16 ğŸ”— â€“ Starship Enterprise. Bought out of Nohoval from Myles Cogan and previously owned by the Burke family, Top of the Hill, Cobh. Fig.3 - Starship Enterprise, 2016. February 2017 saw another success in the finding of the missing prototype boat â€“ The Reynoldâ€™s boat. This was an exciting find as she was a boat that had disappeared off the radar. She was the sister boat to Eddie Twomeyâ€™s Fiona ğŸ”—. She was started in Ericâ€™s Boatyard in 1956. She was found at the back of the Crosshaven Boatyard (in very bad condition) owned by Dick Gibson. A deal was done, John Horgan was the new owner and began the extensive re-construction. After 18 months meticulous restoration work, Freedom V ğŸ”— took to the water. Fig.4 - ï¿¼Freedom V, 2017; photo Mary Kidney. Traced and converted by the group . 2017 also saw the finding of the first of four restoration/ conversion boats traced and restored by the group. Boat no.1 . A punt in bad condition which needed to be converted to a sailing dinghy by the addition of a centre board casing. The skilled repairs and woodwork were led by Dave Oâ€™Keeffe. She was bought by the Kenny/Doyle/Russell consortium and took to the water in 2018 as R25 ğŸ”—. Fig.5 - R25 2018; photo Mary Kidney. Further restored/converted boats followed. Boat no.2 . Found in Kinsale, through contacts of Conor English in 2019 and now owned by the Hudson family as R6 ğŸ”—. Fig.6 - R6 2019. Boat no.3 . Acquired by the group from the Robertâ€™s family in passage West in 2020, converted to a sailing dinghy and sailed by Stephen Barry and family in Cobh as as R31 ğŸ”—. Fig.7 - R31, 2020. Boat no.4 . Acquired by the group from Michael O Driscoll in 2022 â€“ she had been sourced in Cork from friends of Damien and Anne Ahern. Converted from a punt to a sailing dinghy. New owners, Eric Johansson and family. Scheduled to launch Season 2023 R39 ğŸ”—. ï¿¼While the Rankin restoration work was ongoing from 2017 to 2023 other boats were sourced and added to the fleet. Most Notably. | The French boat, R34 ğŸ”—, sourced in France. Repatriated and now owned by Ruiri and Clare Allen. | R13 ğŸ”— - Dominic Lostyâ€™s find in Ardmore â€“ beautifully restored by Jim Walsh in Nohoval. | R4 ğŸ”— - Michael O Driscollâ€™s lovely Bermudan rigged Rankin bought from Tom Crosby. | R30 ğŸ”— - Sourced and repatriated from England by Richard Marshall and beautifully restored. | R21 ğŸ”— - Bought by Colm Oâ€™Connell from Eddie Coakley. Previously owned by Tommy Noonan. Converted to sail and expertly helmed by Fiona O Connell. | . Other Rankins bought that are â€˜works in progressâ€™ â€“ yet to see the water are owned by Jason Losty and James Burke.

3.title: A new Rankin dinghy
3.content: by Owen Oâ€™Connell . Continuing from part 1 ğŸ”— describing significant milestones in building the new Rankin dinghy. May 7, 2021 . Having made the templates for the aft seat assembly the next task is to rough cut out the Iroko close to the line and finish off the pieces on the router table. May 9, 2021 . The consensus was to use a stringer under the side seats (as per the early rankins) for support rather than the â€œ hourglassâ€ support (seen on most of the later Rankins. This was done by making a concave jig to match the seat profile then gluing and screwing a length of 38x18 Siberian Larch in place. May 10, 2021 . All the pieces of the stern seat assembly were laid in the jig, glued and screwed, (the yellow pvc tape was to protect the wood from glue seepage) After 24 hrs the assembly was removed from the jig and cleaned down ( the pvc tape was not the best). May 11, 2021 . All 6 seat supports made using template and router. One edge was then beveled to match the inside curve of the hull while ensuring the top surface remained on the same plane as its opposite number on the other side of the boat. Extra long rebar clamps are used to hold the piece in place while checking the fit. May 18, 2021 . Following glue clean up on the underside of the seat supports, the shell was turned ( Maurice lending a hand) and the aft seat assembly was screwed and glued down, the forward seat is screwed only as it needs to be removed when we come to fit the dagger board box. May 20, 2021 . Working on the struts that support the triangular shaped floorboard and shaping the pieces that make up the daggerboard box using templates and router. May 23, 2021 . Working on making up the daggerboard box, the stiffners on the top and bottom of the â€œboxâ€ kindly milled to size by James Burke, the plastic is to ensure the two sides are no glued together prematurely before a melamine liner is glued to the inside faces of the â€œboxâ€. May 27, 2021 . Dry fitting and fairing the box to the hog before unscrewing the two halves of the box and glueing the melamine lining to the inside of the box. Itâ€™s done in this sequence as the melamine protrudes below the box by the thickness of the hog and keel and therefore would be vulnerable while fairing. June 4, 2021 . Itâ€™s official! The Rankin Dave Oâ€™Keeffe and myself are building is a sailing dinghy. Daggerboard box and mast thwart glued and screwed in place today. June 9, 2021 . Today the Dinosaur was put through its paces as Dave Oâ€™Keeffe and myself bent, glued and clamped lengths of Sepele and Siberian Larch over its back to form the gunnels. June 10, 2021 . Our full stock of 25 clamps was used to hold the 1st of the gunnels in place today. June 16, 2021 . Both inwales fitted with the top strake planed to the sheer. Outwales milled to 20 x 25mm and ready for fitting. (its all gunnels to me!) . June 25, 2021 . The frist of the Iroko floorboards (8mm thick) glued in place, the yellow spacer is used to maintain the gap between the floorboards. June 28, 2021 . Half way there - four floorboards (bottom boards) in and four more to go. July 4, 2021 . All eight bottom boards now in, only 28 more pieces to be fitted and glued in place. Can you identify them? . July 8, 2021 . Spot the difference between this and the last post . July 9, 2021 . Chainplates fitted today and getting on with cutting up an ex wardrobe to make the forward floorboards. July 20, 2021 . Completed the forward set of floor boards today. The wood Honduras Mahogany is courtesy of Eddie English and came in the form of an ex wardrobe. July 22, 2021 . One of those jobs that makes a rankin a Rankin. Aug 10, 2021 . Gunnels fitted with Dave Oâ€™Keeffe, wardrobe varnished and the two midship knees also fitted. Aug 30, 2021 . The quarter knees were fitted today using Iroko. Our first choice, white oak was scuppered by a very cantankerous bandsaw. Aug 31, 2021 . Setting up the rollock plates; two concentric holes are required, one 21mm diameter to take the circular casting and another 14mm to take the 13mm diameter rollock shaft; the plate still needs to be sunk flush with the gunnel. Sept 1, 2021 . All four rollock plates now rebated flush to the gunnel and the mast step cut into the forward thwart using a router. Sept 6, 2021 . Final assembly of the bending jig for the laminated knees this morning and a test run this afternoon using Siberian Larch. Sept 14, 2021 . Making up the breasthook took more than one go to get right, but now itâ€™s glued, fitted and shaped in with the stem and apron. Sept 21, 2021 . A 25mm wide brass keel band tapered to 10mm at the stem was fitted and temporarily screwed in place. The keel itself was tapered down from its max width of 40mm to match the width of the brass band. Sept 24, 2021 . With the end of the woodwork in sight and the keel band fully fitted, it was a good time to rub down and fair the hull, before preparing the shed for the next phase. Sept 25, 2021 . First of two sealer varnish coats overlapping the waterline. Oct 2, 2021 . Following a change of plan and seven build coats of Epfanes Rapid Clear varnish, the hull is ready to receive three top coats of Epfanes Clear varnish. Oct 9, 2021 . Having completed the varnish and refixed the keel band (bedded in Sikaflex), MK was on hand to turn the boat and chew the cud. Oct 14, 2021 . The last laminated knee is glued up and held in place by the bending jig, while some glue lines are taped in readiness of a tidy up. Dec 3, 2021 . The last two laminated knees glued in place and cleaned off, which completes the woodwork. Jan 31, 2022 . New shed - making good the glue lines where required before the vanishing starts. The boat is tipped over to allow the epoxy to flow into the joint between the hog and garboard. Feb 23, 2022 . Last few jobs before the â€œsink testâ€ - taped the margins of the bottom boards and forward floor boards, applied anti-skid coat of varnish and removed after. Also fixed the bronze rowlock plates in the gunnels. April 1, 2022 . Setting up the standing rigging using R13â€™s mast as a template, and as luck would have it, the Sitka Spruce stock was delivered, enough for three sets of spars. April 9, 2022 . Maiden sail today for R61 - the completion of a year long journey - photo courtesy of Adrian Oâ€™Donovan. May 11, 2022 . Mast building. Nov 17, 2022 . Seats for small children as requested by new owner.

5.title: About
5.content: Image: Eithne Twomey . The Rankin dinghy is a 12ft 9in glued plywood clinker boat, powered by sail, oar or outboard motor, produced by the Rankin brothers, Eric and David, at their workshop on Lynchâ€™s Quay in the harbour town of Cobh, Co. Cork, Ireland. Established there at the start of the 1950s, early commissions included 20ft salmon yawls, 15ft and 17ft fishing boats, cold-moulded 5o5s, a set of 30 14ft oars for the Irish Naval Service, a rowing eight for Cork Rowing Club, an Uffa Fox 18 footer and, of course, the Rankin dinghy. The Rankin proved to be a bouyant, safe boat, well suited for family boating adventures in choppy harbour conditions. The first Rankin was built in the early 1960s. The design became very popular and subsequently over 80 were produced until the close of the Rankin workshop in the late 1980s. Thanks to Maurice Kidney and Conor English, who each began to raise awareness of the boat, a â€œRankin revivalâ€ commenced around 2014 and a local, informal group led by Maurice, Conor and Owen Oâ€™Connell convened to promote the class, rescuing and renovating boats, organising sailing events, and even building new Rankins. We are documenting all aspects of this wooden boat class here, including history, the boats themselves, and occasional articles on the ongoing life of the Rankin dinghy class. Email Rankin Dinghy .

22.title: Origins
22.content: Fig 1. Evening Echo, 10-7-1962. "Tom Donovan, Eric Rankin and Dave with one of their 12" 9' dinghies". The first clinker Rankin dinghy was built in the early 1960s. The earliest solid date we have comes from an Evening Echo article of 10 July 1962 which indicates that the Rankin was already in production by then (fig.1). However, the origins of the design date back to the early 1950s when a cold-moulded prototype that gave birth to the clinker class was built by Eddie Twomey (1917-1976) and Eric Rankin (1926?-1975?). Eddie, another Cobh man, was a wooden boat and sailing enthusiast who introduced Eric to boat building in the 1940s. The story of the prototype and its construction are outlined here. In all, only three of the prototype design were built and they are still going strong today. Eddie Twomey left a number of artifacts including line plans, half-model, notes and photos and Ida Hadley (Ericâ€™s sister) supplied what relevant photos she had to the group. Unfortunately, very little survives from the Rankin Lynchâ€™s Quay workshop and the chronology of building the Rankin clinker production boats is more difficult to establish. Fig.2 - Half-model of the cold-moulded dinghy prototype made by Eddie Twomey. Legend states "Prototype of the Rankin 12ft 9in Glued-Clinker Dinghy, built July 1956" (Twomey Collection).

23.title: Timeline
23.content: | 1945 | Eddie Twomey designs and builds Dairne, a variant of the National 12, which subsequently became known as the T class in Cove Sailing Club. Ten of the class were built in total over the next four years. | . | 1946 | Eddie Twomey introduces Eric Rankin, about nine years his junior, to boat building by helping him build his first boat, a T class called Mur Too. | . | 1947 | Eddie builds a second T class boat called Cliodhna. | . | 1948 | Eric builds a second T class boat called Swift. | . | 1949 | Eric builds a third T class boat called Sheldrake on commission for Harmon. | . | ca 1949 | Eric sets up a boat workshop at Batesons Farm, Bellevue, Cobh. | . | ca 1952 | Eric moves workshop to Lynchâ€™s Quay, Cobh. | . | 1955 / 56 | Eddie and Eric collaborate on a new design, a cold-moulded dinghy. Eddie builds Fiona. Eric builds what is now called Freedom V on commission for Dr Reynolds. This design is later adapted by Eric in the 1960s to produce the clinker Rankin. The prototype completion date is July 1956. | . | 1956 | Eric builds his first 5o5, WOW, for Maher; she is completed in late August 1956. | . | 1957 | Eric builds two more first 5o5s: Three Star for Oâ€™Meara, Thalia for Hennessy (CSC). | . | 1957 | Eric closes workshop and moves to the UK. He spent time at three boatyards: Fairey Marine Yard, Southampton, South Devon Boatbuilders Company, Dawlish and Morgan Giles, Teignmouth. | . | 1959? | Eric returns to Cobh and reopens workshop at Lynchâ€™s Quay. | . | 1960 | Eric with brother David, builds the third cold-moulded boat Helga and exhibits her at the Dublin Boat Show winning 2nd prize in the professional builders category. | . | ca 1960 | Eric adapts the forms of the cold-moulded dinghy, adopting a rounder, beamier shape to build the first of the glued plywood clinker design. This may be the Moynihan familyâ€™s Kevdec. | . | 1960s - 1980s | The clinker design is in production (over 80 are built) in various forms (with/without daggerboard case, sailing rigs (e.g., Bermudan, Gunter), seating arrangements, etc). | . | 1994 | Having secured the clinker forms at auction on the close of the Rankin workshop, local woodwork teacher, Dave Oâ€™Keeffe, builds his own Rankin. | . | 2021 | Dave Oâ€™Keeffe leads on the building of a new Rankin, initiating Owen Oâ€™Connell in the craft of boat building. | .

24.title: T Class
24.content: Fig.3 - The T Class dinghy Dairne (Twomey Collection) In a short newspaper profile in 1960 Eric Rankin states that he got into the work of professional boat building through building Cove Sailing Club (CSC) T Class boats. Eddie Twomey had planned and built the first T Class dinghy called Dairne in 1945. Other enthusiasts built their own boats, several helped by Eddie, among them, a neophyte Eric, whom Eddie helped build his first boat called Mur Too in the Rankin family home at Kingâ€™s Terrace. CSC introduced a T Class to its ranks in 1947, ten boats in total being built by 1949. Eddie builds two, Eric three. Other local sailors, JJ Oâ€™Mahoney, P Cotter, Keb Sealy, N Casey and TA Oâ€™Sullivan also built boats.

25.title: Rankin workshop
25.content: By the late 1940s, Eric has set up as a professional boat builder, opening a workshop in Cobh, first at Batesonâ€™s farm, Bellevue and later at Lynchâ€™s Quay. He is established at Lynchâ€™s Quay at the latest by 1952 when Joe Stromsoe begins his apprenticeship there.

26.title: The prototype
26.content: Among the items left by Eddie relating to the prototype, there are a half-model with the prototype build date (fig.2), a lines plan (fig.4) and a comparison of the cost of traditional building (planking) vs cold-moulding (fig.6). The half-model wall mount was made by Eddie for his cousin, Paddy Russell, who owned a Rankin. Fig.4 - Part of lines plan of prototype showing superimposed tender lines (Twomey Collection).

27.title: Construction methods
27.content: The Rankin is built using the clinker/lapstrake method in which plywood planks overlap each other and are secured with glue. However, the prototype of the Rankin design used a very different construction method, that of cold-moulding, in which a series of veneers/laminates is shaped on a mould and glued together to form the hull. Fairey Marine in the U.K., capitalising on their experience building wood-laminate wartime aircraft (as Fairey Aviation Company) marketed one of the first mass-produced laminated dinghies in 1946, the Firefly, an Uffa Fox design. Because of the limitations of the glues at the time, however, those dinghies were hot-moulded by being placed in a large autoclave to enable the glue to set at the higher temperature and pressure required. By the 1950â€™s new glues that would set at room temperature and with sufficient pressure provided by stapling the veneers together became available and this put the technique within reach of the home builder. Fig.5 - Cold-moulded dinghy prototypes Fiona (front) and Reynolds (rear) under construction at Lynch's Quay workshop. The mould or form is visible on the right (Twomey Collection).

28.title: Cold-moulding
28.content: Fig.6 - Back-of-the-envelope comparison of the costs of building planked vs moulded hull (Twomey Collection). The choice of cold-moulding is interesting. Costing was hardly a factor. A back-of-the-envelope estimate (fig.6) of planked vs moulded by Eddie indicates that moulded was somewhat cheaper but the cost does not include the glue. Eddie would certainly have been aware of new building techniques, e.g., a note of his, dated 9 May 1947, in reference to the hot-moulded Firefly around the time of its introduction states â€œskin 3/16â€ resin bonded moulded plyâ€. However, the likely impetus for choosing cold-moulding was the introduction of the cold-moulded 5o5s in 1954. This international class rapidly took off, with workshops like George Bushâ€™s in Ringaskiddy importing hulls for finishing. Cobh man Joe Stromsoe who was an apprentice in Ericâ€™s workshop from 1952 to 1957 remembers accompanying Eddie and Eric on a somewhat alarming passage by sail over to Ringaskiddy to George Bushâ€™s workshop to see the 5o5s being finished there. In contrast, over 1956-57, Eric actually built three 5o5s from scratch. These were Wow for John Maher, Thalia for international rugby player, PJ Oâ€™Meara, and Three Star for H.O. Hennessy. Joe Stromsoe also recalls Oâ€™Meara visiting the workshop with Ted Crosbie who already had his own 5o5 (from George Bushâ€™s workshop in Ringaskiddy). Fig.7 - Eddie Twomey working on the Fiona in the Lynch's Quay workshop. The Reynolds boat is just about visible in the upper right (Twomey Collection). It was J. Clayton Love who introduced the 5o5 class to Ireland. His boat, Miss Betty II made her debut in a race from Crosshaven to Aghada on 24th April 1955. By 1957 there were four in the class in Cork Harbour, the latest being Oâ€™Mearaâ€™s Three Star. By July 1957, the 5o5 class in the IDRA championships in Crosshaven included 12 entries, seven being Irish and five from Cork. We know that Eric completed the Maher boat WOW in August 1956, a month after the completion of the prototypes, because the Cork Examiner, 23rd August 1956, had a piece on the Maher 5o5 indicating that she was the first one built in the country: . A boat â€¦ now lying on Robinsonâ€™s Slip in Cobh â€¦ is the 5-0-5 WOW built to the order of those well known Cork Harbour sailing brothers Messrs R. and M. Maher by the young Cobh boat-builder Mr. Eric Rankin in his workshops on Lynchâ€™s Quay â€¦ The boat, first of its class to be built in Ireland â€¦ . In photos of the Lynchâ€™s Quay workshop around 1955/56 the Fiona and Reynolds boat are shown with a 5o5 mould in the background suggesting that 5o5 construction was occurring concurrently (although why the WOW was launched late, missing the 1956 sailing season, is hard to explain). In another photo, two 5o5s are under construction simultaneously with no sign of the Rankin prototypes. We can surmise that these are the Oâ€™Meara and Hennessy boats, under construction in 1956/57 as we know Oâ€™Mearaâ€™s boat made her debut in 1957. This adoption of the cold-moulding technique in 1955/56 must surely put the prototypes amongst the first cold-moulded boats to be built in Ireland.

29.title: UK sojourn
29.content: In late 1957 (as confirmed by Joe Stromsoe and Ida Hadley) Eric moved to England to work. He spent time at three workshops: Fairey Marine Yard, Southampton, South Devon Boatbuilders Company, Dawlish and Morgan Giles, Teignmouth. Details become scarce at this stage - about how long Eric was away - but he did resume building at Lynchâ€™s Quay by 1960. In that year, with his brother David, he built the third of the cold-moulded dinghies and an 8ft yacht tender version. These were displayed in Dublin during Easter week at a boat show that was raising funds to send a yachting team to the Olympic Games. The Rankins won 2nd prize in the professional builders category. This third boat became Ericâ€™s own boat and was named Helga. Fig.8 - The three cold-moulded dinghies together: (l to r) Fiona, Freedom V, Helga. (Image courtesy of Marion Horgan). Only three full sized cold-moulded dinghies were made although Eric may have built some additional boat tenders. The three dinghies are still going strong after 60+ years (fig.8), the Fiona with Eddie Twomeyâ€™s grandson, James Burke, the Helga with Owen Oâ€™Connell, and the Reynolds boat (now named Freedom V), recently bought and beautifully renovated by John Horgan. It must be said that without the expert sleuthing of Maurice Kidney, the Helga and Reynolds boat might not be back in Cobh.

30.title: The gluelap era
30.content: Fig.9 - Eric (helm) and Eddie sailing a clinker Rankin. This is one of the early builds, if not the first (Rankin Collection). Eric may have been incentivised to explore methods of â€œmass productionâ€ based on what he experienced in the UK boat yards which led to the clinker version of what subsequently became the standard Rankin dinghy. The clinker version would be less labour intensive to produce than the cold-moulded one. In any case, Eric adapted the forms of the cold-moulded dinghy to make the clinker one (as related to Ã‰amonn Twomey by his father Eddie). Eddie appears to have still been involved in the testing and rigging of the new design (fig.9,10) but hereon fades out of the picture. The new revised design proved to be popular and over the next three decades the Rankin workshop headed by Eric and later David and with the assistance of several associates and apprentices produced some 80+ boats. Fig.10 - Eddie and Eric sailing in an early Bermudan rigged clinker Ranklin (Rankin Collection).

31.title: Acknowledgements
31.content: Thanks to Owen Oâ€™Connell for sharing newspaper archive search results, Dermot Burns (archivist, RCYC), for pinning down some 5o5 dates and Conor English for providing contacts. And a special thank you to Ida Hadley for sharing her memories of brother Ericâ€™s early days in boat building and to Joe Stromsoe for sharing his reminiscences of his apprenticeship in Ericâ€™s workshop on Lynchâ€™s Quay.

32.title: R
32.content: Owner . Cobh Sea Scouts . Provenance . The Sea Scoutsâ€™ Rankin spotted south of Spike Island going through her paces. The boat was given to the Cobh Sea Scouts by the late Bob Thomson. Fig.1 . Fig.2

34.title: R
34.content: Owner . Jason Losty . Provenance . The punt was bought out of Mogeely in 2020 by Dom Losty on behalf of his brother. The punt is now in the UK and is being converted to sail by Jason. Fig.1 . Fig.2

37.title: R
37.content: Owner . Provenance . This punt was recently aquired by the Rankin Dinghy Class from the Muckley family of Youghal. The boat is in very good condition and is scheduled to be converted to a dinghy over the coming winter and join the fleet for the 2024 season. Fig.1- The Muckley family punt at the Sir Walter Raleigh Festival some years ago.

38.title: R
38.content: Owner . Gavin Jeffery . Provenance . In 2023, Gavin Jeffery discovered this Rankin punt in his Grandadâ€™s garage where she had been kept safe for the previous 30 to 35 years. She is in good order and ready for another 35 years on the water. Fig.1- The Jeffery Rankin punt.

39.title: R1 - Kevdec
39.content: Owner . Declan Moynihan . Provenance . Believed to be the first of the glued plywood clinker dinghies, launched by 1962. Remains under ownership of the Moynihan family and now in hands of Declan Moyhihan. R1 is similar to Andrew Cockburnâ€™s boat ğŸ”—. Both have the Helga style hanging thwarts with laminated ends. They have side seats that extend forward to the mast thwart and, of course, both are Bermudan rigged. Fig.1 . Fig.2

40.title: R11
40.content: Owner . Mills family . Provenance . Ray Mills bought the dinghy directly from the Rankin workshop in the mid 70s. At that time Rayâ€™s garage and the Rankin workshop were neighbours on Lynchâ€™s quay. R11 is very much a production boat with off centre box. Fig.1

41.title: R12
41.content: Owner . Maurice Kidney . Provenance . Bought by my father as a new build from Dave Rankin in 1986, she has been in the family ever since. R12 is one of the mass production boats Dave built towards the latter stages of the Rankin Boat building operation. At that stage Dave was building the hulls of up to 3 boats at a time, stacking them into each other and fitting them out afterwards when a new buyer arrived. Hence the off line centreboard casing in our boat and many of the boats of this period. She has been well used as a family boat, with a child in a moses basket a regular feature in the bow of the boat in the early days. You wouldnâ€™t get away with it today. Laterally the R12 has given much enjoyment in the CSC Dinghy Racing League, proving quite successful. Being overall League winner in 2019, 2021 and 2022. R12 was also honoured with Boat of the Year in 2022 by CSC â€“ the first time a dinghy was awarded this trophy. Fig.1 - Rounding the Spit (photo: Robert Bateman) . Fig.2 -(photo: Mary Kidney)

42.title: R13 Turn Key
42.content: Owner . Dominic Losty . Provenance . We were lucky to hear about R13 in May 2018, from a friend who advised that a person in Ardmore had a Rankin for sale. It was used for years as a punt. Having spent many hours and days trying to bring her back to her former glory we handed the boat over to Jim Walsh who did a fantastic job on her. R13 would seem to sit in the middle of a design transition. She has all the hallmarks of an early purpose build Rankin: full length risers supporting the seats, 9mm ply, slight curve to the aft seat, three wide bottom boards each side of the hog. Yet the daggerboard box is off centre. The boat is mainly used for our kids who love playing around during the summer months in Dungarvan. As they get older, we hope to do more racing in Cobh. Fig.1 - R13, on the day it arrived. Fig.2 - R13 . Fig.3 - R13

44.title: R14
44.content: Owner . Dan Oâ€™Regan . Provenance . R14 and R6 ğŸ”— are similar. Fig.1 - A very new Rankin at the entrance to Kidney's Strand.

45.title: R15
45.content: Owner . John Hudson . Provenance . Originally a punt, she was bought by the Class as a project boat in 2018 fron Frank Godsil of Kinsale through the good conections of Conor English. John Hudson bought her early in the conversion cycle and had bronze chain plates fitted. She was initially allocated â€œR6â€. However, over time it became apparent the number was inappropriate for the nuances of the boat, and with the blessing of John she has been renumbered as â€œR15â€. She is very much the sane as R14 ğŸ”—. They both had foredecks (unfortunatly R15â€™s was removed during conversion as it was beyond repair). Both have the alternative thwart knee design and full length risers to support the thwarts and a runner support under the side seats. Both are built of 5/8 ply. The only difference is R15 was built as a punt and R14 was a purpose built dinghy. Fig.1 . Fig.2 . Fig.3

46.title: R16
46.content: Owner . Damian Ahern . Provenance . One of the fiist boats to come into Cork Harbour following the launch of the Rankin Revival. R16 won the Rankin Brothersâ€™ Cup in 2016. Fig.1

47.title: R17
47.content: Owner . Aine Oâ€™Callaghan . Provenance . The present owner bought the boat in 2022 and is an active member of the class. The boat was bought from John Doyle who had her since 1979. John sailed her over the years and flew the Rankin flag at many a Cove Sailing Club event. John bought her from a Jim Dolan who had her for at least 2 years. She has been renumbered to align with the known build sequence of the boats. She has an off centre box and the bow floor boards have been raised to accommodate a bouyancy bag. Fig.1 R17 .

48.title: R1976
48.content: Owner . Paul Hegarty . Provenance . The Dinghy is a production boat. It was the first Rankin to aquire North Sails at the start of the Rankin Revival. She is based in West Cork over the summer months. Fig.1

49.title: R2
49.content: Owner . Andrew Cockburn . Provenance . The dinghy was built for Dan Casey in the 60â€™s. She was kept on the Gas Works beach. Alan Horgan restored the boat about 2015 and sold to John King who sold to Andrew Cockburn the current owner. She is though to be one of the very early Rankins. Fig.1

50.title: R20
50.content: Owner . Stewart Meehan . Provenance . Fig.1 . Fig.2

51.title: R21
51.content: Owner . Fiona Oâ€™Connell . Provenance . She is a production Rankin probably built in the late 70â€™s. Her first known owner was Tommy Noonan. The Noonanâ€™s had a foredeck fitted complete with a windscreen and nav light They used her as a little runabout based in the Western Camber. Tommy sold her to Eddy Coakley. In 2017, Eddy sold her to Colm Oâ€™Connell. After various attempts she was finally converted to sail in 2019 when Fiona took the boat on. The boat is a three time winner of the Rankin Brothersâ€™ Regatta Cup - 2020 and 2022 when sailed by Fiona and 2021 when sailed by her brother Dan. Fig.1 . Fig.2

52.title: R22
52.content: Owner . Doireann Wallace . Provenance . Bought by John Wallace of Whitepoint, Cobh in 1990. Brother, Eugene, recalls tall ships in 1991 being a highlight. Used by family in Cobh until Johnâ€™s death. His daughter Doirean used the boat and loaned it to Eugene in Wexford so necessary upkeep and secure storage could happen. Boat repairs to preserve hull integrity carried out. Delamination of plywood due to water ingress beneath aft seat. All varnish removed from interior and resealed. Boat still in secure dry storage for occasional use in Wexford. No numbers visible on any part of hull including transom. Fig.1 . Fig.2 . Fig.3

53.title: R25
53.content: Owner . Dave Doyle . Provenance . This Rankin was originally a punt and became our 1st project boat in 2017, having been bought from Glandore. She required quite a bit of work in the conversion as most of the keel, hog and both garboards need to be renewed. Fig.1 . Fig.2 . Fig.3

54.title: R26
54.content: Owner . Colin Barry . Provenance . Previous owner- Carrie Dunne, living in Kinsale but originally from Cobh. Fig.1 . Fig.2 . Fig.3

55.title: R28
55.content: Owner . Anthony Oâ€™Leary . Provenance . R28 was originally commissioned by Mary English in the early 1970s. The Englishâ€™s enjoyed the boat for many years around Cork harbour and West Cork and it was subsequently sold to Anthony Oâ€™Leary in the mid 1980s. The Oâ€™Leary family had Dick Gibson restore the boat in the early 2000s and the extended family continue to enjoy the boat today in Crosshaven and Baltimore, West Cork. Anthony with crew Sally Oâ€™Leary sailed the boat in convoy with the Rankin fleet to Cobh and Crosshaven when Ida Rankin (sister of Eric and David Rankin) visited from the UK in 2018. More recently the boat had a starring role in an national AIB advert on television screens regarding climate sustainability filmed in Lough Hyne, West Cork. Fig.1 - Rankin Commemorative Sailing, 2018 . Fig.2 - Eddie English in R28, Baltimore, 1976. Fig.3 - R28 in Lough Hyne for AIB advert.

56.title: R29
56.content: Owner . Tom Dwyer . Provenance . Fig.1 - Tom Dwyer at the 2022 Rankin Brothers' Regatta Cup race. Fig.2 - Tom Dwyer at the 2022 Rankin Brothers' Regatta Cup race. Fig.3 - The Dwyers' Boat sailed by Anthony Coole during a Rankin Brothers' Regatta Cup race.

57.title: R3
57.content: Owner . Martin Ã“ Treasaigh . Provenance . Early Rankin with hung curved thwarts and centre line daggerboard. It has forward and aft bouyancy tanks/lockers and is gaff rigged. It was owned by James Oâ€™Leary (Current owner of GRP K3) in the late 1990s and sold to Joe English, who had Mark Bushe carry out repairs. Englishs then sold this in 2012 to Martin Ã“ Treasaigh who enjoys the boat with family in West Cork. Fig.1 - Joe and April English sailing their Rankin in 2006. Fig.2 - Crosbie Punt (left) and Ã“ Treasaigh boat (right) Currabinny Pier. Fig.3 - Ã“ Treasaigh family sailing, West Cork.

58.title: R30
58.content: Owner . Richard Marshall . Provenance . This production Rankin dinghy was purchased by Richard in 2021. She was repatriated from the UK having been there for many years. Richard restored her and she is now in tip top condition and an active member of the racing scene. Fig.1

59.title: R31
59.content: Owner . Stephen Barry and family . Provenance . R31 was previously a punt owned by Norcott Roberts and kept in his garage in Monkstown for many years. Following his death the Class were invited to buy her by his family in 2019 and she became that yearâ€™s project boat. The Barry family bought the boat early in the conversion process and are an active part of the Class. Fig.1 . Fig.2

60.title: R32
60.content: Owner . Killian Thighe & Family . Provenance . This is a production Rankin, off center box and gunter rig. Fig.1

61.title: R33 - Arc
61.content: Owner . Robbie & Conor English . Provenance . R33 was originally built by David Rankin in the mid 1970s for the Hennessy Family from Currabinny for sailing and exploring the Owenabue river. It was sold to Dick Gibson in the late 2000s who carried out an extensive restoration in Crosshaven. It was then owned briefly by Coleman Garvey who subsequently sold it to the English Family, Crosshaven in 2012 (after the Englishâ€™s sold their previous Rankin Dinghy to Martin Oâ€™ Treasaigh). With funding by the Heritage Council, The Marine Institute and individuals including Hal Sisk under the â€˜Traditional Boats of Ireland Projectâ€™, R33 was point cloud laser scanned by Pat Tanner as a record for the Rankin Dinghy. tradboats.ie ğŸ”—) . In 2019 Robbie & Conor English sailing R33, won the Rankin World Cup held during Cork Dinghy fest at the Royal Cork YC and were also the Cork Dinghy Fest overall Champions. In 2021 the boat was the mixed dinghy champion at the RCYC 300 Tricentenary at home regatta. Apart from sailing, the Englishâ€™s use R33 as a punt/tender in Crosshaven and in Schull, exploring the harbours and islands of West Cork. A Family Tradiion . The English Family have a proud tradition with the Rankin boats. The English siblings used to spend a lot of time in the Rankin brothersâ€™ yard growing up in the 1960s/70s. Mary English commissioned a Rankin (R28) in the 1970s, in which John Paul English spent time learning to sail and was brought down to West Cork on Summer holidays. This boat is now owned by Anthony Oâ€™Leary & Family. Many students learned to sail on the several Rankin boats working hard at Eddie Englishâ€™s sailing school based in Cobh, including several custom made boats by David Rankin. Joe English, as a sailmaker and with his knowledge of the boat, tweaked and perfected the sail area and shape of the sail, particularly the jib design, that has now become the standard in the class. Fig.1 . Fig.2 Fig.3

62.title: R34
62.content: Owner . Ruairi Allen . Provenance . The dinghy was repatriated from France by Ray Murray in 2019 and sold to the Class who passed her on to the Allen Family. She is currently undergoing some inhouse TLS by Ruairi. Fig.1

63.title: R39
63.content: Owner . Eric Johansson & family . Provenance . Having just bought the â€œ2023 Project Rankinâ€, Eric becomes the newest owner in the fleet. The boat was a production punt, bought by Michael Oâ€™Driscolll in 2021 from a Cork family who previously lived in Currabinny and used it as a means of transport to cross the Owenabue. Micheal sold the punt to the Rankin Dinghy Class in 2022. She is due to complete her conversion by the start of the 2023 sailing season. Fig.1 .

64.title: R4
64.content: Owner . Michael Oâ€™Driscoll . Provenance . An early purpose built sailing Dinghy. The current owner bought her from Tom Crosbie in 2022. The boat was part of the Crosbie family for many years allowing young sailors to cut their teeth. Fig.1 - Andrew Crosbie sailing in the Rankin Worlds 2019 at the RCYC.

65.title: R5
65.content: Owner . ? . Provenance . The previous owner, Colum O Sullivan, bought a house with a Rankin when he moved to Kinsale. She was then given the â€œDick Gibson treatmentâ€ and restored to perfection. Colum sailed her in Kinsale over the years, as well as participating in the Rankin Brothersâ€™ Regatta Cup races. Fig.1 . Fig.2

66.title: R60
66.content: Owner . Dave Oâ€™Keeffe . Provenance . Dave built this boat in 1997 following his purchase of tbe jig and templates some years earlier when the contents of the Rankin workshop were sold off. Fig.1 - Ewan and Dave O'Keeffe sailing R60 in the Rankin Brothers' Regatta Cup 2021.

67.title: R61
67.content: Owner . Dan Oâ€™Connell & family . Provenance . A brand new boat launched in 2022, having been built over the previous 16 months as a lockdown project by Dave Oâ€™Keeffe and Owen Oâ€™Connell. (See New Rankin blog series for more info.) Her number, R61, was chosen as she was built 61 years after the 1st production Rankin came off the jig and was the 1st of the 60 series. I bought her late in 2022 and had additional side seats fitted between the thwarts to accommodate the younger members of the family. Fig.1 - R61, maiden sail, May 2022. Fig.2 - R61, finished internals, December 2022.

68.title: R7 - Puffin
68.content: Owner . Gerry Collins and family . Provenance . This early Rankin is a purpose build dinghy. Gerry had her in safe keeping for a number of years before putting her in the hands of Dick Gibson who carried out the work to perfection. Jim Walsh did the woodwork and plank repairs. Fig.1 - The Puffin in foreground on Whitepoint slip. Fig.2 - Raising a young crew in Rankin racing.

69.title: R70
69.content: Owner . Johnny Wigham . Provenance . Johnny Wigham has owned this production Dinghy for many years using it for fishing and sailing and is an active Class member. Fig.1 . Fig.2

70.title: R77
70.content: Owner . Peter McQuade . Provenance . I inherited the Rankin from my grandfather who was from Cork city but lived in Killarney for over 50 years, where he used the Rankin for sailing on the lakes and on Kenmare Bay. It spent much of the last ten years under some bushes, but fortunately very carefully wrapped in tarps, near Caherciveen in west Kerry. We are gradually getting it back into commission, albeit storage conditions are still not ideal. Last year we got a new trailer and an outboard, and managed to get her out on the water a number of times here in Dublin. This year we ordered sails from NorthSails but they took longer to arrive than anticipated. We still have some way to go to (Gunter) rig her, as the original mast was rotten. We have a replacement mast and yard but we are missing some fittings. Fig.1

71.title: R8
71.content: Owner . Rachel Leigh . Provenance . This dinghy is one of the few Rankins based overseas. She is an early purpose built dinghy with centre line box. She is Bermudan rigged boat with three wide bottom boards each side of the hog. The aft seat has a slight concave curve to its forward element and the thwarts are supported by a riser that runs near on full length of the boat. Fig.1 .

72.title: R9
72.content: Owner . Declan Scott . Provenance . R9 is an early Bermudan rigged purpose built dinghy like R8 ğŸ”—. Declan Scott bought the boat from Dave Rankin, the deal being done on the steps opposite the Customs House on Lynchâ€™s Quay as Dave emerged from the water. The boat was kindly lent by Declan to the Rankin Dinghy Class for the Rankin Worlds held at the RCYC in 2019. Fig.1 - R9 being prepared for Rankin Worlds held at RCYC, 2019. Fig.2 - Dave Rankin with R9 on Kidney's Strand. Entrance to workshop is on left. Fig.3 - R9 under way with Dave Rankin at helm.

73.title: TR1 - Fiona
73.content: Owner . James Burke . Provenance . The Fiona is one of the prototypes ğŸ”— of the Rankin class, built by Eddie Twomey in 1956. She has remained with the Twomey family ever since and is now in the hands of Eddieâ€™s grandson, James Burke. Eddie experimented with various sailing rigs over the years but the boat was primarily used as a family runabout for exploring the harbour, trips taking place almost every weekend throughout the summer season. The boat was kept on Kidneyâ€™s Strand adjoining the Rankin workshop and was stowed in the workshop over winter (for at least her first decade). Spars and Seagull outboard were also housed in the workshop and Eddie retained his own key for access. Fig.1 . Fig.2 . Fig.3 - Exploring the harbour, ca. 1960.

74.title: TR2 - Freedom V
74.content: Owner . Johnny Horgan . Provenance . Built for Dr Reynolds, Montenotte, Cork. Used mainly on lakes. Later owned by the Daly family. The boat lay in a Crosshaven boatyard for many years until tracked down by Maurice Kidney. She was then bought and restored by Johnny Horgan. Fig.1 - Freedom V at the 2021 Rankin Brothers' Regatta Cup race.

75.title: TR3 - Helga
75.content: Owner . Owen & Eithne Oâ€™Connell . Provenance . Helga was built in March 1960 by Eric Rankin. She was the last of the three prototypes to be built, all of which were cold-moulded. She was exhibited in April 1960 in the first Irish Boat Show held in Dublin, where Eric won second prise in the Professional Builders category. She remained in his ownership until his death in 1975. She was then sold to Mick Brennen of Kinsale who had her until we bought her in 2016. She was beautifully restored by Jim Walsh that year, I have since replaced the keel in 2022. Fig.1 - Helga, sailing back from Ballinacurra, July 2021. Fig.2 - Helga, when bought in April 2016. Fig.3 - Helga, emerging from Jim Walsh's workshop, May, 2016.
